description: Main themes on Russian Primetime TV news on NTV, Rossiya 1 and Channel One on 4 June. President Vladimir Putin took centre stage today owing to what Russian networks described as his prompt intervention to arrest the spread of coronavirus in a Siberian region and launch a major clean-up operation following a disastrous fuel spill near the Arctic city of...
text:
Main themes on Russian Primetime TV news on NTV, Rossiya 1 and Channel One on
4 June

President Vladimir Putin took centre stage today owing to what Russian
networks described as his prompt intervention to arrest the spread of
coronavirus in a Siberian region and launch a major clean-up operation
following a disastrous fuel spill near the Arctic city of Norilsk.
'Environmental catastrophe' in the Arctic

All three channels led with the Norilsk fuel spill story and were upfront
about the extent of the damage.

Gazprom Media's NTV described the incident as a "true environmental
catastrophe".

State-controlled Channel One TV used similar language, saying the damage was
"catastrophic" and would take decades to undo. Its correspondent said the
sight of the contaminated river was "horrifying".

Reports showed excerpts from yesterday's televised video call during which
Putin upbraided officials for not reporting the incident and shifting
responsibility onto each other.

"Immediately" after that meeting work began to stop contamination and start
extracting the spillage from the water and soil, the viewers were told,
praising Putin's personal role in handling the aftermath of the incident.
Putin requests support for Transbaikal Territory

The main theme in tonight's coverage of coronavirus in Russia was President
Putin's order to the Defence Ministry to send help to Transbaikal region,
which has found itself in a difficult situation.

Channel One praised what it described as the president's timely intervention
in the outbreak in the southern Siberian region.

Video showed a column of army trucks setting off from neighbouring Buryatia.
They are carrying dozens of medics and "most modern" equipment, Channel One
said.

All three channels reported the latest nationwide - and in some cases regional
- numbers.

However, while NTV said that Russia today recorded nearly 9,000 cases (the
exact number was 8,831), Channel One's take was that the number of new cases
had stayed below the 10,000 mark for 20 days in a row.

Official state Rossiya 1 said that "overall the situation is stabilising".
Russians said backing constitutional amendments

All three channels reported on the state pollster VTsIOM's findings to the
effect that two-thirds of Russians intend to go to the polls on 1 July when
amendments to the constitution allowing Vladimir Putin to seek two more terms
in office will be put to a vote.

Of them, about 60 per cent intend to vote yes, according to VTsIOM. The vast
majority of Russians reportedly think it will be safe to go to the polls
despite the pandemic. Thank you to US for ventilators

Rossiya 1 and Channel One praised the US for giving Russia another 150
ventilators.

The former pointed out that the ventilators came complete with manuals in
Russian, and that the consumer watchdog, Rospotrebnadzor, had already
confirmed they were of high quality.

Rossiya 1 said the US sent the aid "remembering" that the Russians had helped
the Americans at their time of need.

Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova was shown saying that this is an
"excellent example of cooperation" between the two countries in times of
trouble.

Channel One said Russia and the US had mounted a united front against the
pandemic.

The delivery of US ventilators is a "valued gesture", it said. Trump
'disingenuous', Johnson 'ready for global effort'

NTV was critical of Donald Trump and complimentary of Boris Johnson in a
report about today's online Global Vaccine Summit 2020, which was hosted by
the UK.

It appeared to accuse Trump of hypocrisy, saying he sounded disingenuous when
speaking about partnership. Johnson on the other hand is, it appears, ready to
back a global effort in developing coronavirus vaccines, the TV's
correspondent said.

The report also said that there was particular interest in Russian studies
because they had "real schedules". US protests 'more peaceful', but
administration and country said divided

All three channels continued to cover the protests in the US sparked by the
killing by a white police officer of a black man.

The thrust of reports was different however.

NTV said that while protests continued across much of America they had
definitely become more peaceful with no major clashes occurring over the past
24 hours.

Rossiya 1 and Channel One highlighted divisions between Donald Trump and his
senior officials, and between Washington and states. Channel One also said the
Democrats were seeking to use the protests to their advantage in the
presidential election.

Rossiya 1 pointed out apparent divisions between Trump and his defence
secretary.

Channel One presenter Kirill Kleymyonov blamed Democrats for the riots saying
the worst instances of disorder occurred in states run by Democratic
governors.

He also accused Democrats of resorting to "theatrics" in expressing their
solidarity with the protesters.

He said America's separation of powers had proved to be its weakness, not
strength. He also appeared to accuse the National Guard of weakness.

"This picture is a symbol" of the state of America, he said over an image of
its members taking a knee with protesters.

We do not have this and I hope we shall never have, he said. US racism 'built
in UK'

Channel One presenter Kirill Kleymyonov took another swipe at the West when
commenting on protests in Europe.

"This is probably called trans-Atlantic solidarity. It is now clear what this
phrase means," he said.

Channel One said racism was an issue in Britain as much as in America.

Its UK correspondent highlighted an opinion piece in The Guardian which said
that "the racism that killed George Floyd was built in Britain".

Over footage of the protest in London the correspondent said that "these
people's slogan is 'Britain is not innocent'",

Source: BBC Monitoring in Russian 1900 gmt 4 Jun 20

title: Russian TV news: Putin deals with Arctic 'catastrophe', Covid outbreak
html:
Main themes on Russian Primetime TV news on NTV, Rossiya 1 and Channel One on 4 June

President Vladimir Putin took centre stage today owing to what Russian networks described as his prompt intervention to arrest the spread of coronavirus in a Siberian region and launch a major clean-up operation following a disastrous fuel spill near the Arctic city of Norilsk. 'Environmental catastrophe' in the Arctic

All three channels led with the Norilsk fuel spill story and were upfront about the extent of the damage.

Gazprom Media's NTV described the incident as a "true environmental catastrophe".

State-controlled Channel One TV used similar language, saying the damage was "catastrophic" and would take decades to undo. Its correspondent said the sight of the contaminated river was "horrifying".

Reports showed excerpts from yesterday's televised video call during which Putin upbraided officials for not reporting the incident and shifting responsibility onto each other.

"Immediately" after that meeting work began to stop contamination and start extracting the spillage from the water and soil, the viewers were told, praising Putin's personal role in handling the aftermath of the incident. Putin requests support for Transbaikal Territory

The main theme in tonight's coverage of coronavirus in Russia was President Putin's order to the Defence Ministry to send help to Transbaikal region, which has found itself in a difficult situation.

Channel One praised what it described as the president's timely intervention in the outbreak in the southern Siberian region.

Video showed a column of army trucks setting off from neighbouring Buryatia. They are carrying dozens of medics and "most modern" equipment, Channel One said.

All three channels reported the latest nationwide - and in some cases regional - numbers.

However, while NTV said that Russia today recorded nearly 9,000 cases (the exact number was 8,831), Channel One's take was that the number of new cases had stayed below the 10,000 mark for 20 days in a row.

Official state Rossiya 1 said that "overall the situation is stabilising". Russians said backing constitutional amendments

All three channels reported on the state pollster VTsIOM's findings to the effect that two-thirds of Russians intend to go to the polls on 1 July when amendments to the constitution allowing Vladimir Putin to seek two more terms in office will be put to a vote.

Of them, about 60 per cent intend to vote yes, according to VTsIOM. The vast majority of Russians reportedly think it will be safe to go to the polls despite the pandemic. Thank you to US for ventilators

Rossiya 1 and Channel One praised the US for giving Russia another 150 ventilators.

The former pointed out that the ventilators came complete with manuals in Russian, and that the consumer watchdog, Rospotrebnadzor, had already confirmed they were of high quality.

Rossiya 1 said the US sent the aid "remembering" that the Russians had helped the Americans at their time of need.

Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova was shown saying that this is an "excellent example of cooperation" between the two countries in times of trouble.

Channel One said Russia and the US had mounted a united front against the pandemic.

The delivery of US ventilators is a "valued gesture", it said. Trump 'disingenuous', Johnson 'ready for global effort'

NTV was critical of Donald Trump and complimentary of Boris Johnson in a report about today's online Global Vaccine Summit 2020, which was hosted by the UK.

It appeared to accuse Trump of hypocrisy, saying he sounded disingenuous when speaking about partnership. Johnson on the other hand is, it appears, ready to back a global effort in developing coronavirus vaccines, the TV's correspondent said.

The report also said that there was particular interest in Russian studies because they had "real schedules". US protests 'more peaceful', but administration and country said divided

All three channels continued to cover the protests in the US sparked by the killing by a white police officer of a black man.

The thrust of reports was different however.

NTV said that while protests continued across much of America they had definitely become more peaceful with no major clashes occurring over the past 24 hours.

Rossiya 1 and Channel One highlighted divisions between Donald Trump and his senior officials, and between Washington and states. Channel One also said the Democrats were seeking to use the protests to their advantage in the presidential election.

Rossiya 1 pointed out apparent divisions between Trump and his defence secretary.

Channel One presenter Kirill Kleymyonov blamed Democrats for the riots saying the worst instances of disorder occurred in states run by Democratic governors.

He also accused Democrats of resorting to "theatrics" in expressing their solidarity with the protesters.

He said America's separation of powers had proved to be its weakness, not strength. He also appeared to accuse the National Guard of weakness.

"This picture is a symbol" of the state of America, he said over an image of its members taking a knee with protesters.

We do not have this and I hope we shall never have, he said. US racism 'built in UK'

Channel One presenter Kirill Kleymyonov took another swipe at the West when commenting on protests in Europe.

"This is probably called trans-Atlantic solidarity. It is now clear what this phrase means," he said.

Channel One said racism was an issue in Britain as much as in America.

Its UK correspondent highlighted an opinion piece in The Guardian which said that "the racism that killed George Floyd was built in Britain".

Over footage of the protest in London the correspondent said that "these people's slogan is 'Britain is not innocent'",

Source: BBC Monitoring in Russian 1900 gmt 4 Jun 20
